awd_titl_txt: CREST   Center for Complex Materials Design for Multidimensional Additive Processing (CoManD)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Centers of Research Excellence in Science and Technology (CREST) program supports the enhancement of research capabilities of minority-serving institutions through the establishment of centers that effectively integrate education and research. CREST promotes the development of new knowledge, enhancements of the research productivity of individual faculty, and an expanded presence of students historically underrepresented in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics disciplines.  

With CREST program support, Florida Agricultural and Mechanical University will establish the Center for Complex Materials Design for Multidimensional Additive Processing.  The Center will promote advancements in the manufacture of novel combined materials in the micrometer scale for applications in magnetic shielding, energy and bio-medical technology. The ability to pattern multiple materials, on micrometer length scales, in three dimensions is critical for several technological applications including composites, microfluidics, photonics, and tissue engineering. The Center will be comprised of an interdisciplinary team of faculty from Chemical and Biomedical Engineering, Industrial Engineering, Biological and Agricultural Systems Engineering, Chemistry, Pharmaceutical Sciences and Physics.

Simulations coupled with experiments will result in a molecular level understanding of the forces governing self-assembly in different materials. Printing of three dimensional tumor cell cultures on a chip using appropriate hydrogels will allow evaluation of the cytotoxicity of anticancer drugs and nanoparticles. Enhanced cell efficiency of printed photovoltaic cells will impact applications in portable electronics and power generation in automotive and space applications. The combined effect of flow and magnetic field induced orientation of novel nanoparticles will result in lightweight materials with enhanced dielectric properties for shielding and sensing applications.

Undergraduate courses based on fundamentals of self-assembly, nanoparticle synthesis and characterization, additive manufacturing, nanomaterials in biology, and nanoparticles in medicine will be developed and offered to Florida Agricultural and Mechanical University students. A laboratory course in materials will be offered to graduate and undergraduate students involved in materials research. The Center will produce 15 Ph.Ds., directly impact 40 undergraduates and influence 100 graduate students and 300 undergraduates through collaborations and coursework.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ele.pgm_ele_name: Centers for Rsch Excell in S&T

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: CENTERS FOR RSCH EXCELL IN S&T

por.por_cntn:
Complex Materials Design for Multidimensional Additive Processing (CoManD) –The goal of CoManD was to combine the expertise of faculty at FAMU to develop an integrated research and education program on Additive Manufacturing (AM) which not only meets the technological demands of the 21st century but also trains the next generation of scientists and engineers at Florida A&M University, a Historically Black Research University. The initial targets were to produce 15-20 PhD’s, directly impact 30-40 undergraduates and have an influence on ~100 graduate students and ~300 undergraduates through research collaborations and coursework. Research objectives of CoManD Center were to assemble novel materials (by self-assembly) and further control assembly from the micro to macro scale by field assisted (flow, electric and magnetic fields) processing and AM. Fundamental studies result in novel design rules for materials processing.  To date, we have graduated 13 PhDs, 6 master’s students, with 17 currently enrolled doctoral students. Further, we trained 11 postdoctoral scholars and have involved more than 100 undergraduate students in our research through our programs and summer Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REUs). We produced 75 peer reviewed publications, 6 patents and developed key collaborations with leading institutions such as Harvard, MIT, the U.S. Army, and U.S. Air Force. Faculty involved in Phase I raised over $10 million and helped develop a sustainable research infrastructure.  The key developments in the CREST research included Structure – Dynamics – Function relationships in soft materials with development of novel X-ray scattering tools at national labs (Argonne and Brookhaven) to study structure and dynamics especially during 3D printing. CREST research impacts also included development of novel 2D materials and the ability to synthesize them using different elements for flexible electronics; the ability to combine field and flow induced processing to obtain enhanced properties;  the development of novel solid-state polymers with tunable printing parameters for enhanced device morphological control;4  and establishing a relationship between cell seeding density and alginate molecular weight on hydrogel viscoelastic properties, printability, and cell viability.

CoManD created record “firsts” at FAMU – first FAMU professor to  obtain a Young Investigator Award from the Department of Defense (DOD), first (DOD) SMART student fellowship at FAMU, first Harriet Jenkins NASA fellow at FAMU, first FAMU Ph.D. student hired as a permanent civilian at the U.S. Air Force, first FAMU student hired as a postdoc at Harvard, first place awards at conference presentations, summer fellowships at National Labs and DOD labs, first Purdue ‘Black Trailblazer in Engineering” fellow. Additionally, CREST provided successful research experiences for undergraduates serving 15-20 students every year with the creation of, Honors in the Major at FAMU for the first time – with CREST students being the first students to participate in the program. A major outcome was the development of a Graduate Program in Materials Science and Engineering for the first time at FAMU. In terms of additional funding, CREST enabled the successful procurement of NSF CREST Postdoctoral Research Program grants and Dear Intern opportunities at industries. The grant was instrumental in the hire of two African American faculty at FAMU, including the first joint hire between chemical engineering and chemistry, to establish closer collaborations. The faculty have been extremely successful with grants, including an NSF Partnerships for Research and Education in Materials seed award. A junior faculty member was featured in Chemical and Engineering News as a Trailblazer among Black Chemists and Engineers. The PI achieved full professorship, is currently a 3M distinguished professor, and the recipient of the Joseph Cannon Award from National Organization of Chemists and Chemical Engineers and Distinguished Service Award from the American Institute of Chemical Engineers. Other key faculty achievements include promotion to associate professor and tenure (3 professors), NSF Career Awards, Emerging Researcher Awards at FAMU, Distinguished Research Award, Fulbright Scholar Awards, National Academy of Engineering Frontiers of Engineering Alum (first at FAMU). The facilities set up by Phase I position FAMU to address a wide variety of problems. Equipment grants (3D printer with laser annealing, six axis printing, Xray micro CT, Atomic Force Microscopy, Bioprinters, Dielectric Spectrometer, Nanoscribe 3D printer, Confocal Microscope) have led to a state-of-the-art characterization facility at FAMU, greatly enhancing the research capability and sustainability of FAMU faculty, while providing students with an unparalleled education.  For the first time, a user facility was created with purchased equipment, enabling next-level faculty-led research on materials, supporting the establishment of a NASA center on InSpace Manufacturing at FAMU.


Last Modified: 04/01/2025
Modified by: Subramanian Ramakrishnan
